div1.p: EVERY ONE HAS HIS FAULT: A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS, AS IT IS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR G. G. J. AND J. ROBINSON, PATERNOSTER-ROW. 1793.

lg.l: OUR Author, who accuses great and small,
And says so boldly, there are faults in all;
Sends me with dismal voice, and lengthen'd phiz,
Humbly to own one dreadful fault of his:
A fault, in modern Authors not uncommon,
It is,—now don't be angry—He's—a woman.
Can you forgive it? Nay, I'll tell you more,
One who has dar'd to venture here before;
Has seen your smiles, your frowns,—tremendous sight!
O, be not in a frowning mood to-night!
The Play, perhaps, has many things amiss:
Well, let us then reduce the point to this,
Let only those that have no failings, hiss.
The Rights of Women, says a female pen,
Are, to do every thing as well as Men.
To think, to argue, to decide, to write,
To talk, undoubtedly—perhaps, to fight.
[For Females march to war, like brave Commanders,
Not in old Authors only—but in Flanders.]
I grant this matter may be strain'd too far,
And Maid 'gainst Man is most uncivil war:
I Grant, as all my City friends will say,
That Men should rule, and Women should obey:
That nothing binds the marriage contract faster,
Than our—a "Zounds, Madam, I'm your Lord and Master."
I grant their nature, and their frailty such,
Women may make too free—and know too much.
But since the Sex at length has been inclin'd
To cultivate that useful part—the mind;—
Since they have learnt to read, to write, to spell;—
Since some of them have wit,—and use it well;—
Let us not force them back with brow severe,
Within the pale of ignorance and fear,
Confin'd entirely to domestic arts,
Producing only children, pies, and tarts.
The fav'rite fable of the tuneful Nine,
Implies that female genius is divine.
Then, drive not, Critics, with tyrannic rage,
A supplicating Fair-one from the Stage;
The Comic Muse perhaps is growing old,
Her lovers, you well know, are few and cold.
'Tis time then freely to enlarge the plan,
And let all those write Comedies—that can.

div1.head: EVERY ONE HAS HIS FAULT: A COMEDY.

div3.stage: Enter Mr. PLACID and Mr. SOLUS.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: YOU are to blame.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I say the same by you.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: And yet your singularity pleases me; for you are the first elderly bachelor I ever knew, who did not hug himself in the reflection, that he was not in the trammels of wedlock.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: No; I am only the first elderly bachelor who has truth and courage enough to confess his dissatisfaction.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: And you really wish you were married?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I do. I wish still more, that I had been married thirty years ago. Oh! I wish a wife and half-a-score children would now start up around me, and bring along with them all that affection, which we should have had for each other by being earlier acquainted. But as it is, in my present state, there is not a person in the world I care a straw for; and the world is pretty even with me, for I don't believe there is a creature in it who cares a straw for me.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Pshaw! You have in your time been a man of gallantry; and, consequently, must have made many attachments.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Yes, such as men of gallantry usually make. I have been attached to women who have purloined my fortune, and to men who have partaken of the theft: I have been in as much fear of my mistress as you are of your wife.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Is that possible?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Yes; and without having one of those tender, delicate ties of a husband, an excuse for my apprehension.—I have maintained children—

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Then why do you complain for the want of a family?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p:
I did not say I ever had any children; I said I had maintained them; but I never believed they were mine; for I could have no dependence upon the principles of their mother—and never did I
take one of those tender infants in my arms, that the forehead of my Valet, the squint-eye of my Apothecary, or the double-chin of my Chaplain, did not stare me in the face, and damp all the fine feelings of the parent, which I had just called up.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: But those are accidents which may occur in the marriage state.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: In that case, a man is pitied—in mine, he is only laughed at.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: I wish to heaven I could exchange the pity which my friends bestow on me, for the merriment which your ill fate excites.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: You want but courage to be envied.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Does any one doubt my courage?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: No. If a Prince were to offend you, you would challenge him, I have no doubt.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: But if my wife offend me, I am obliged to make an apology.—Was not that her voice? I hope she has not overheard our conversation.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: If she have, she'll be in an ill humour.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: That she will be, whether she have heard it or not.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Well, good-day. I don't like to be driven from my fixed plan of wedlock; and, therefore, I won't be a spectator of your mutual discontent.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: But before you go, Mr. Solus, permit me to remind you of a certain concern, that, I think, would afford you much more delight, than all you can, at this time of life, propose to yourself in marriage. Make happy by your beneficence, a near relation whom the truest affection has drawn into that state, but who is denied the blessing of competency to make the state supportable.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: You mean my nephew, Irwin? But do not you acknowledge he has a wife and children? Did not he marry the woman he loved, and has he not, at this moment, a large family, by whom he is beloved? And is he not, therefore, with all his poverty, much happier than I? He has often told me, when I have reproached him with his indiscreet marriage, "that in his wife he possessed kingdoms!" Do you suppose I will give any part of my fortune to a man who enjoys such extensive domains? No:—let him preserve his territories, and I will keep my little estate for my own use. Exit.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: John! John!— Enter Servant Has your mistress been enquiring for me?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Yes, Sir:—My Lady asked just now, if I knew who was with you?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Did she seem angry?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: No, Sir;—pretty well.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: You scoundrel, what do you mean by "pretty well?"In anger.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Much as usual, Sir.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: And do you call that "pretty well?" You scoundrel, I have a great mind—

div3.stage: Enter Mrs. PLACID, speaking very loud.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: What is the matter, Mr. Placid? What is all this noise about? You know I hate a noise. What is the matter?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: My dear, I was only finding fault with that blockhead.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Placid, do not find fault with any body in this house. But I have something which I must take you very severely to talk about, Sir.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: No, my dear, not just now, pray.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Why not now?

sp.speaker: PLACID,
sp.p:
Because dinner will be ready in a few minutes. I am very hungry, and it will be cruel of you
to spoil my appetite. John, is the dinner on table?

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: No, John, don't let it be served yet—Mr. Placid, you shall first hear what I have to say.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: But then I know I sha'n't be able to eat a morsel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Sit down. He sits—I believe, Mr. Placid, you are going to do a very silly thing. I am afraid you are going to lend some money?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Well, my dear, and suppose I am?

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Then, I don't approve of people lending their money.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: But, my dear, I have known you approve of borrowing money: And, once in our lives, what should we have done, if every body had refused to lend?

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: That is nothing to the purpose.—And now I desire you will hear what I say, without speaking a word yourself.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Well, my dear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p:
Now mind you don't speak, till I have done. —Our old acquaintance, Captain Irwin, and Lady
Eleanor, his wife (with whom we lived upon very intimate terms, to be sure, while we were in America), are returned to London; and I find you have visited them very frequently.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Not above two or three times, upon my word; for it hurts me to see them in distress, and I forbear to go.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: There! You own they are in distress; I expected as much. Now, own to me that they have asked you to lend them money.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: I do own it—I do own it. Now, are you satisfied?

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: No: for I have no doubt but you have promised they shall have it.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: No, upon my word, I have not promised.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Then promise me they shall not.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Nay, my dear, you have no idea of their distress!

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Yes, I have; and 'tis that which makes me suspicious.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p:
His regiment is now broken; all her jewels and little bawbles are disposed of; he is in such dread of his old creditors, that, in the lodging they have taken, he passes by the name of Middleton—They have three more children, my dear, than when
we left them in New England; and they have in vain sent repeated supplications, both to his uncle, and her father, for the smallest bounty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: And is not Lord Norland, her father, a remarkably wise man? and a good man? And ought you to do for them, what he has refused?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: They have offended him, but they have never offended me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: I think 'tis an offence to ask a friend for money, when there is no certainty of returning it.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: By no means: for, if there were a certainty, even an enemy might lend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: But I insist, Mr. Placid, that they shall not find a friend in you upon this occasion.—What do you say, Sir?

sp.speaker: PLACID,
sp.p: No, my dear, they shall not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Positively shall not?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Positively shall not—since they have found an enemy in you.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Dinner is on table.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Ah! I am not hungry now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: What do you mean by that, Mr. Placid? I insist on your being hungry.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Oh yes! I have a very excellent appetite. I shall eat prodigiously.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: You had best. Exeunt.

div3.stage: Enter Mr. HARMONY followed by Miss SPINSTER.

sp.speaker: Miss SPINSTER.
sp.p: Cousin, cousin Harmony, I will not forgive you for thus continually speaking in the behalf of every servant whom you find me offended with. Your philanthropy becomes insupportable; and, instead of being a virtue, degenerates into a vice.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Dear Madam, do not upbraid me for a constitutional fault.

sp.speaker: Miss SPINSTER.
sp.p: Very true; you had it from your infancy. I have heard your mother say you were always foolishly tender-hearted, and never shewed one of those discriminating passions of envy, hatred, or revenge, to which all her other children were liable.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p:
No: since I can remember, I have felt the most unbounded affection for all my fellow creatures. I even protest to you, dear Madam, that, as I walk along the streets of this large metropolis, so warm is my heart towards every person who passes me, that I long to say, "How do you do?" and
"I am glad to see you," to them all. Some men, I should like even to stop and shake hands with;— and some women, I should like even to stop and kiss.

sp.speaker: Miss SPINSTER.
sp.p: How can you be so ridiculous!

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis truth: and I sincerely lament that human beings should be such strangers to one another as we are. We live in the same street, without knowing one another's necessities; and oftentimes meet and part from each other at church, at coffee-houses, play-houses, and all public places, without ever speaking a single word, or nodding "Good bye!" though 'tis a hundred chances to ten we never see one another again.

sp.speaker: Miss SPINSTER.
sp.p: Let me tell you, kinsman, all this pretended philanthropy renders you ridiculous. There is not a fraud, a theft, or hardly any vice committed, that you do not take the criminal's part, shake your head, and cry, "Provisions are so scarce!" And no longer ago than last Lord-mayor's-day, when you were told that Mr. Alderman Ravenous was ill with an indigestion, you endeavoured to soften the matter, by exclaiming, "Provisions are so scarce!"—But, above all, I condemn that false humanity, which induces you to say many things in conversation which deserve to stigmatize you with the character of deceit.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p:
This is a weakness I confess. But though my honour sometimes reproaches me with it as a fault, my conscience never does: for it is by this very failing that I have frequently made the bitterest
enemies friends—Just by saying a few harmless sentences, which, though a species of falsehood and deceit, yet, being soothing and acceptable to the person offended, I have immediately inspired him with lenity and forgiveness; and then, by only repeating the self-same sentences to his opponent, I have known hearts cold and closed to each other, warmed and expanded, as every human creature's ought to be.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Mr. Solus. Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: Miss SPINSTER.
sp.p: I cannot think, Mr. Harmony, why you keep company with that old bachelor; he is a man, of all others on earth, I dislike; and so I am obliged to quit the room, though I have a thousand things to say. Exit angrily.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Mr. Solus, how do you do?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I am very lonely at home; will you come and dine with me?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Now you are here, you had better stay with me: we have no company; only my cousin Miss Spinster and myself.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: No, I must go home: do come to my house.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Nay, pray stay: what objection can you have?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Why, to tell you the truth, your relation, Miss Spinster, is no great favourite of mine; and I don't like to dine with you, because I don't like her company.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: That is, to me, surprising!

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Why, old bachelors and old maids never agree: we are too much alike in our habits: we know our own hearts so well, we are apt to discover every foible we would wish to forget, in the symptoms displayed by the other. Miss Spinster is peevish, fretful and tiresome, and I am always in a fidget when I am in her company.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: How different are her sentiments of you! for one of her greatest joys is to be in your company. Solus starts and smiles Poor woman! she has, to be sure, an uneven temper—

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: No, perhaps I am mistaken.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: —But I will assure you, I never see her in half such good humour as when you are here: for I believe you are the greatest favourite she has.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I am very much obliged to her, and I certainly am mistaken about her temper—Some people, if they look ever so cross, are good-natured in the main; and I dare say she is so. Besides, she never has had a husband to sooth and soften her disposition; and there should be some allowance made for that.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Will you dine with us?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I don't care if I do. Yes, I think I will. I must however step home first:—but I'll be back in a quarter of an hour.—My compliments to Miss Spinster, if you should see her before I return.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: My lady begs to know, Sir, if you have invited Mr. Solus to dine? because if you have, she shall go out. Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I could not help inviting him; for, poor man, his own house is in such a state for want of proper management, he cannot give a comfortable dinner himself.

sp.speaker: Miss SPINSTER.
sp.p: And so he must spoil the comfort of mine.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Poor man! poor man! after all the praises he has been lavishing upon you.

sp.speaker: Miss SPINSTER.
sp.p: What praises?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I won't tell you; for you won't believe them.

sp.speaker: Miss SPINSTER.
sp.p: Yes, I shall.—Oh no—now I recollect, this is some of your invention.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Nay, I told him it was his invention: for he declared you looked better last night, than any other lady at the Opera.

sp.speaker: Miss SPINSTER.
sp.p: No, this sounds like truth: —and, depend upon it, though I never liked the manners of Mr. Solus much, yet—

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Nay, Solus has his faults.

sp.speaker: Miss SPINSTER.
sp.p: So we have all.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: And will you leave him and me to dine by ourselves?

sp.speaker: Miss SPINSTER.
sp.p: Oh no, I cannot be guilty of such ill manners, though I talked of it. Besides, poor Mr. Solus does not come so often, and it would be wrong not to shew him all the civility we can. For my part, I have no dislike to the man; and, if taking a bit of dinner with us now and then can oblige either you or him, I should be to blame to make any objection. Come, let us go into the drawing-room to receive him.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Ay! this is right: this is as it should be.

head.stage: A Room at the Lodgings of Mr. IRWIN.

div3.stage: Mr. IRWIN and Lady ELEANOR IRWIN discovered.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: My dear husband, my dear Irwin, I cannot bear to see you thus melancholy. Is this the joy of returning to our native country after a nine years banishment?

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p:
Yes. For I could bear my misfortunes, my
wretched poverty with patience, in a land where our sorrows were shared by those about us; but here, in London, where plenty and ease smile upon every face; where, by birth you claim distinction, and I by services:—here to be in want,—to be obliged to take another name in shame of our own,—to tremble at the voice of every stranger, for fear he should be a creditor,—to meet each old acquaintance with an averted eye, because we would not feel the pang of being shunned.—To have no reward for all this, even in a comfortable home; but there, to see our children looking up to me for that support I have not in my power to give—Can I,—can I love them and you, and not be miserable?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: And yet I am not so. And I am sure you will not doubt my love to you or them.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: I met my uncle this morning, and was mean enough to repeat my request to him;—he burst into a fit of laughter, and told me my distresses were the result of my ambition, in marrying the daughter of a nobleman, who himself was too ambitious ever to pardon us.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Tell me no more of what he said.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: This was a day of trials:—I saw your father too.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: My father! Lord Norland! Oh Heavens!

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: He passed me in his carriage.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I envy you the blessing of seeing him! For, Oh!—Excuse my tears —he is my father still.— How did he look?

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: As well as he did at the time I used to watch him from his house, to steal to you.—But I am sorry to acquaint you, that, to guard himself against all returning love for you, he has, I am informed, adopted a young lad, on whom he bestows every mark of that paternal affection, of which you lament the loss.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: May the young man deserve his tenderness better than I have done—May he never disobey him —May he be a comfort, and cherish his benefactor's declining years—And when his youthful passions teach him to love, may they not, like mine, teach him disobedience!

div3.stage: Enter a SERVANT with a letter.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: What is that letter?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: It comes from Mr. Placid, the servant who brought it, said, and requires no answer. Exit.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p:
It's strange how I tremble at every letter I see, as if I dreaded the contents. How poverty has unmann'd me! aside—I must tell you, my dear, that finding myself left this morning without a guinea, I wrote to Mr. Placid to borrow a small sum. This is his answer: reading the superscription "To Mr. Middleton"—That's right;—he remembers the caution I gave him. I had forgot whether
I had, for my memory is not so good as it was. I did not even recollect this hand, though it is one I am so well acquainted with, and ought to give me joy rather than sorrow Opens the letter hastily, reads, and lets it drop. Now I have not a friend on earth.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Yes, you have me. You forget me.

sp.speaker: IRWIN,
sp.p: I would forget you—you—and all your children.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I would not lose the remembrance of you, or of them, for all my father's fortune.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: What am I to do? I must leave you! I must go, I know not where! I cannot stay to see you perish. Takes his hat, and is going.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR,
sp.p: Where would you go? 'Tis evening—'tis dark —Whither would you go at this time?

sp.speaker: IRWIN,
sp.p: I must consider what's to be done—and in this room my thoughts are too confined to reflect.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: And are London streets calculated for reflection?

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: No;—for action. To hurry the faint thought to resolution.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: You are not well—Your health has been lately impaired.—Your temper has undergone a change too:—I tremble lest any accident—

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: What accident?Wildly

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I know your provocations from an ungrateful world: But despise it, as that despises you.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: But for your sake, I could.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Then witness, Heaven! I am happy.—Though bred in all the delicacy, the luxury of wealth and splendour; yet I have never murmured at the change of fortune, while that change has made me wife to you, and mother of your children.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: We will be happy—if possible. But give me this evening to consider what plan to fix upon.— There is no time to lose; we are without friends —without money—without credit.—Farewell for an hour.—I will see Mr. Placid, if I can; and though he have not the money to lend, he may, perhaps, give me some advice.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Suppose I call on her? Women are sometimes more considerate than men, and—

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Do you for the best, and so will I.—Heavens bless you!Exeunt separately.

head.stage: A Coffee or Club-room at a Tavern.

div3.stage: Enter Sir ROBERT RAMBLE—and Mr. SOLUS and Mr. PLACID at the opposite Side.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: SIR Robert Ramble, how do you do?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: My dear Mr. Solus, I am glad to see you. I have been dining by myself, and now come into this public room to meet with some good company.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Ay, Sir Robert, you are now reduced to the same necessity which I frequently am—I frequently am obliged to dine at taverns and coffee-houses, for want of company at home.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Nay, I protest I am never happier than in a house like this, where a man may meet his friend without the inconvenience of form, either as a host or a visitor.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Sir Robert, give me leave to introduce to you Mr. Placid: he has been many years abroad; but I believe he now means to remain in his own country for the rest of his life. This, Mr. Placid, is Sir Robert Ramble.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.p: Sir, I shall be happy in your acquaintance; and I assure you, if you will do me the honour to meet me now and then at this house, you will find every thing very pleasant. I verily believe, that since I lost my wife, which is now about five months ago, I verily believe I have dined here three days out of the seven.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Have you lost your wife, Sir? And so lately?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.p: Yes, Sir; about five months ago—Is it not, Mr. Solus? You keep account of such things better than I do.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Oh! ask me no questions about your wife, Sir Robert; if she had been mine, I would have had her to this moment.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: What, wrested her from the gripe of death?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: No, Sir; only from the gripe of the Scotch lawyers.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: More shame for you. Shame! to wish to be divorced from a virtuous wife.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Was that the case? Divorced from a virtuous wife! I never heard of such a circumstance before. Pray, Sir Robert very anxiously, will you indulge me, by letting me know in what manner you were able to bring about so great an event?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: It may appear strange to you, Sir; but my wife and I did not live happy together.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Not at all strange, Sir; I can conceive—I can conceive very well.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Yes; he can conceive that part to a nicety.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And so, I was determined on a divorce.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: But then her character could not be unimpeached.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Yes, it was, Sir. You must know, we were married in Scotland, and by the laws there, a wife can divorce her husband for breach of fidelity; and so, though my wife's character was unimpeached, mine was not, and she divorced me.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: And is this the law in Scotland?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: It is. Blessed, blessed country! that will bind young people together before the years of discretion—and, as soon as they have discretion to repent, will unbind them again!

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: I wish I had been married in Scotland.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: But, Sir Robert, with all this boasting, you must own that your divorce has greatly diminished your fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.p: Mr. Solus, you have frequently hinted at my fortune being impaired; but I do not approve of such notions being received abroad.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I beg your pardon; but every body knows that you have played very deep lately, and have been a great loser, and every body knows—

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: No, Sir, every body does not know it, for I contradict the report wherever I go. A man of fashion does not like to be reckoned poor, no more than he likes to be reckoned unhappy. We none of us endeavour to be happy, Sir, but merely to be thought so; and for my part, I had rather be in a state of misery, and envied for my supposed happiness, than in a state of happiness, and pitied for my supposed misery.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: But consider, these misfortunes which I have just hinted at, are not of any serious nature, only such as a few years oeconomy—

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: But were my wife and her guardian to become acquainted with these little misfortunes, they would triumph in my embarrassments.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Lady Ramble triumph! They join Mr. Placid She who was so firmly attached to you, that I believe nothing but a compliance with your repeated request to be separated, caused her to take the step she did.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Yes, I believe she did it to oblige me, and I am very much obliged to her.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: As good a woman, Mr. Placid—

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Very good—but very ugly.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: She is beautiful.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.p: I tell you, Sir, she is hideous. And then she was grown so insufferably peevish.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I never saw her out of temper.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Mr. Solus, it is very uncivil of you to praise her before my face. Lady Ramble, at the time I parted with her, had every possible fault both of mind and person, and so I made love to other women in her presence; told her bluntly that I was tired of her; that I was very sorry to make her uneasy, but that I could not love her any longer.—And was not that frank and open?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Oh! that I had but such a wife as she was!

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I must own I loved her myself when she was young.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Do you call her old?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: In years I am certainly older than she; but the difference of sex makes her a great deal older than I am. For instance, Mr. Solus, you have often lamented not being married in your youth; but if you had, what would you have now done with an old wife, a woman of your own age?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Loved and cherished her.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: What, in spite of her loss of beauty?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: When she had lost her beauty; most likely I should have lost my eye-sight, and have been blind to the wane of her charms.

sp.speaker: PLACID,
sp.p: But, Sir Robert, you were explaining to me— Mr. Solus, give me leave to speak to Sir Robert —I feel myself particularly interested on this subject.—And, Sir, you were explaining to me—

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Very true: Where did I leave off? Oh! at my ill usage of my Lady Ramble. Yes, I did use her very ill, and yet she loved me. Many a time, when she has said to me, "Sir Robert, I detest your principles, your manners, and even your person," often, at that very instant, I have seen a little sparkle of a wish peep out of the corner of one eye, that has called to me, "Oh! Sir Robert, how I long to make it up with you!"

sp.speaker: SOLUS,
sp.p: Do not you wish that your wife had such a little sparkle at the corner of one of her eyes?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert,
sp.p: Sir, do you wish to be divorced?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: I have no such prospect. Mrs. Placid is faithful, and I was married in England.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: But if you have an unconquerable desire to part, a separate maintenance will answer nearly the same end—for if your Lady and you will only lay down the plan of separation, and agree—

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: But, unfortunately, we never do agree!

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Then speak of parting as a thing you dread worse than death; and make it your daily prayer to her, that she will never think of going from you—She will determine upon it directly.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: I thank you; I'm very much obliged to you: I thank you a thousand times.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Yes, I have studied the art of teasing a wife; and there is nothing vexes her so much as laughing at her. Can you laugh, Mr. Placid?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: I don't know whether I can; I have not laughed since I married.—But I thank you, Sir, for your instructions—I sincerely thank you.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: And now, Sir Robert, you have had the good nature to teach this Gentleman how to get rid of his wife, will you have the kindness to teach me how to procure one?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Hah! Sure I know that Gentleman's face?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: My Nephew! Let me escape his solicitations Aside—Here, waiter!Exit.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Irwin! Starting Having sent him a denial, I am ashamed to see him. Aside Here, Mr. Solus!— Exit, following Mr. SOLUS.

sp.speaker: IRWIN,
sp.p: More cool faces! My necessitous countenance clears even a club-room.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: My dear Captain Irwin, is it you? Yes, 'faith it is—After a nine years' absence I most sincerely rejoice to see you.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Sir Robert, you shake hands with a cordiality I have not experienced these many days, and I thank you.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: But what's the matter? You seem to droop— Where have you left your usual spirits? Has absence from your country changed your manners?

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: No, Sir; but I find some of my countrymen changed. I fancy them less warm, less friendly than they were; and it is that which, perhaps, has this effect upon me.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Am I changed?

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: You appear an exception.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And I assure you, that instead of being grown more gloomy, I am even more gay than I was seven years ago; for then, I was upon the point of matrimony—but now, I am just relieved from its cares.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: I have heard as much. But I hope you have not taken so great an aversion to the marriage-state, as never to marry again.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Perhaps not: But then it must be to some rich heiress.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: You are right to pay respect to fortune. Money is a necessary article in the marriage contract.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: As to that—that would be no great object at present. No, thank Heaven, my estates are pretty large; I have no children; I have a rich Uncle, excellent health, admirable spirits; — and thus happy, it would be very strange if I did not meet my old friends with those smiles, which never for a moment quit my countenance.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: In the dispensation of the gifts of Providence, how few are found blest like you!Sighing.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And I allure you, my dear Mr. Irwin, it gives me the most serious reflections, and the most sincere concern, that they are not.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir, most heartily: I thank you for mankind in general, and for myself in particular. For after this generous, unaffected declaration (with less scruple than I should to any man in the world) I will own to you, that I am at this very time in the utmost want of an act of friendship.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.p: And so am I—Now must I confess myself a poor man; or pass for an unfeeling one; and I will choose the latter. Bowing with great ceremony and coldness, Any thing that I can command, is at your service.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Why then, Sir Robert—I am almost ashamed to say it—but circumstances have been rather unfavourable.—My wife's father affecting to smile is not reconciled to us yet—My regiment is broke —My Uncle will not part with a farthing.—Lady Eleanor, my wife, wipes his eyes has been supported as yet, with some little degree of tenderness, elegance; and—in short, I owe a small sum which I am afraid of being troubled for; I want a trifle also for our immediate use, and if you would lend me a hundred pounds—though, upon my honour, I am not in a situation to fix the exact time when I can pay it.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: My dear Sir, never trouble yourself about the time of paying it, because it happens not to be in my power to lend it you.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Not in your power? I beg your pardon; but have not you this moment been saying you are rich?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And is it not very common to be rich without money? Are not half the town rich? And yet half the town has no money. I speak for this end of the town, the West end. The Squares, for instance, part of Piccadilly, down St. James's-street, and so home by Pall Mall. We have all, estates, bonds, drafts, and notes of hand without number; but as for money, we have no such thing belonging to us.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p:
I sincerely beg your pardon. And be assured, Sir, nothing should have induced me to have taken
the liberty I have done, but the necessities of my unhappy family, and having understood by your own words, that you were in affluence.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I am in affluence, I am, I am; but not in so much, perhaps, as my hasty, inconsiderate account may have given you reason to believe. I forgot to mention several heavy incumbrances, which you will perceive are great drawbacks on my fortune.—As my wife sued for the divorce, I have her fortune to return; I have also two sisters to portion off—a circumstance I totally forgot. But, my good friend, though I am not in circumstances to do what you require, I will do something that shall be better. I'll wait upon your father-in-law, (Lord Norland) and entreat him to forgive his daughter: and I am sure he will if I ask him.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Impossible.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And so it is, now I recollect: for he is no other than the guardian of my late wife, and a request from me, will be received worse than from any other person. — However, Mr. Irwin, depend upon it, that whenever I have an opportunity of serving you, I will. And whenever you shall do me the favour to call upon me, I shall be heartily glad to see you. If I am not at home, you can leave your card, which, you know, is all the same, and depend upon it, I shall be extremely glad to see you or that, at any time. Exit.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p:
Is this my native country? Is this the hospitable land which we describe to strangers? No—We are savages to each other; nay worse—The savage
makes his fellow-savage welcome; divides with him his homely fare; gives him the best apartment his hut affords, and tries to hush those griefs that are confided in his bosom—While in this civilized city, among my own countrymen, even among my brother officers in the army, and many of my nearest relations, so very civilized they are, I could not take the liberty to enter under one roof, without a ceremonious invitation, and that they will not give me. I may leave my card at their door, but as for me, or any one of mine, they would not give us a dinner; unless, indeed, it was in such a style, that we might behold with admiration their grandeur, and return still more depressed, to our own poverty.—Can I bear this treatment longer? No, not even for you, my Eleanor. And this takes out a pistol shall now be the only friend to whom I will apply—And yet I want the courage to be a villain.

div3.stage: Enter Mr. HARMONY, speaking as he enters.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Let me see half a dozen newspapers—Every paper of the day.

sp.speaker: WAITER.
sp.p: That is about three dozen, Sir.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Get a couple of porters, and bring them all.

div3.stage: He sits down; they bring him papers, and he reads—Irwin starts, sits down, leans his head on one of the tables, and shews various signs of uneasiness; then comes forward.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p:
Am I a man, a soldier?—And a coward? Yes,
I run away, I turn my back on life—I forsake the post, which my commander, Providence, has allotted me, and fly before a banditti of rude misfortunes. Rally me, love, connubial and parental love, rally me back to the charge! No, those very affections sound the retreat. Sits down with the same emotions of distraction as before.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: That gentleman does not seem happy. I wish I had an opportunity of speaking to him. Aside.

sp.speaker: IRWIN
sp.p: But Oh! my wife, what will be your sufferings when I am brought home to your wretched habitation!—And by my own hand!

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I am afraid, Sir, I engross all the news here.

sp.speaker: IRWIN,
sp.p: Poor soul, how her heart will be torn!

sp.speaker: HARMONY,
sp.p: Captain Irwin, till this moment I had not the pleasure of recollecting you! It is Mr. Irwin, is it not?

sp.speaker: IRWIN,
sp.stage: His mind deranged by his misfortunes.
sp.p: Yes, Sir: But what have you to say to him more than to a stranger?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p:
Nothing more, Sir, than to apologize to you, for having addressed you just now in so familiar a manner, before I knew who you were; and to assure you, that although I have no other knowledge of you, than from report, and having been once, I believe, in your company at this very
house before you left England; yet, any services of mine, as far as my abilities can reach, you may freely command.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, do you live at the West end of the town?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Then, Sir, your services can be of no use to me.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Here is the place where I live, here is my card.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: And here is mine. And now I presume we have exchanged every act of friendship, which the strict forms of etiquette, in this town, will admit of.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: By no means, Sir. I assure you my professions never go beyond my intentions; and if there is any thing that I can serve you in—

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Have you no sisters to portion off? no lady's fortune to return? Or, perhaps, you will speak to my wife's father, and entreat him to forgive his child.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: On that subject you may command me; for I have the honour to be intimately acquainted with Lord Norland.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: But is there no reason you may recollect, "why you would be the most unfit person in the world to apply to him?"

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: None. I have been honoured with marks of his friendship for many years past; and I do not know any one who could, with less hazard of his resentment, venture to name his daughter to him.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Well, Sir, if you should see him two or three days hence, when I am set out on a journey I am going, if you will then say a kind word to him for my wife and children, I'll thank you.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I will go to him instantly. Going.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: No, do not see him yet; stay till I am gone. He will do nothing till I am gone.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: May I ask where you are going?

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: No very tedious journey; but it is a country, to those who go without a proper passport, always fatal.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I'll see Lord Norland to-night: perhaps I may persuade him to prevent your journey. I'll see him to-night, or early in the morning, depend upon it.—I am a man of my word, Sir; though I must own I do live at the West end of the town.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p:
'Sdeath, am I become the ridicule of my fellow-creatures? or am I not in my senses?—I know this is London—this house a tavern—I know I have a wife. Oh! 'twere better to be mad than to remember her! She has a father—he is rich and proud—that I will not forget. But I will pass his house, and send a malediction as I pass it— furiously.
No; breathe out my last sigh at his inhospitable door, and that sigh shall breathe—forgiveness. Exit.

div3.stage: Enter Mrs. PLACID, followed by Lady ELEANOR IRWIN.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I am ashamed of the trouble I have given you, Mrs. Placid. It had been sufficient to have sent me home in your carriage; to attend me yourself was ceremonious.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: My dear Lady Eleanor, I was resolved to come home with you, as soon as Mr. Placid desired I would not.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Was that the cause of your politeness? I am sorry it should.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Why sorry? It is not proper he should have his way in every thing.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: But I am afraid you seldom let him have it at all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Yes, I do.—But where, my dear, is Mr. Irwin?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR,
sp.p: I cannot hear the name of Mr. Irwin without shedding tears: his health has been so much impaired of late, and his spirits so bad—sometimes I even fear for a failure in his mind. Weeps again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Is not he at home?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I hope he is Goes to the side of the scenes. Tell your master, Mrs. Placid is here.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: My master is not come in yet, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Not yet? I am very sorry for it;—very sorry indeed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Bless me, my dear, don't look thus pale. Come sit down, and I'll stay with you till he returns.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: My dear, you forget that Mr. Placid is in the carriage at the door all this time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: No, I don't. Come, let us sit and have half an hour's conversation.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Nay, I insist upon your going to him, or desiring him to walk in.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Now I think of it, they may as well drive him home, and come back for me. Enter Mr. PLACID. Why surely, Mr. Placid, you were very impatient! I think you might have waited a few minutes longer.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: I would have waited, my dear, but the evening is so damp.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Ah! 'tis the evening, which makes me alarmed for Mr. Irwin.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Lady Eleanor, you are one of the most tender, anxious, and affectionate wives I ever knew.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: There! Now he wishes he was your husband— He admires the conduct of every wife but his own, and envies every married man of his acquaintance. But it is very ungenerous of you.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: So it is, my dear; and not at all consistent with the law of retaliation; for I am sure there is not one of my acquaintance who envies me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Mr. Placid, your behaviour throughout this whole day has been so totally different to what it ever was before, that I am half resolved to live no longer with you.

sp.speaker: PLACID,
sp.p: It will do—It will do.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Oh, my dear friends, do not talk of parting: how can you, while every blessing smiles on your union? Even I, who have reason to regret mine, yet, while that load of grief, a separation from Mr. Irwin, is but averted, I will think every other affliction supportable. A loud rapping at the door. That is he.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Why, you seem in raptures at his return.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I know no greater rapture.

div3.stage: Enter IRWIN pale, trembling, and disordered.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: My dear, you are not well, I see.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Yes.— Aside to her in anger—Why do you speak of it?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: How do you do, Irwin?

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: I am glad to see you. Bows.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: But I am sorry to see you look so ill.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: I have only been taking a glass too much.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Pshaw! Don't I know you never drink?

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: You are mistaken: I do when my wife is not by. I am afraid of her.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Impossible.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: What! To be afraid of one's wife?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: No; I think that very possible.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p:
But it does not look well when it is so; it makes a man appear contemptible, and a woman a termagant. Come, Mr. Placid, I cannot stay another moment. Good night. Heaven bless you! To Lady Eleanor—Good night, my dear Mr. Irwin;
and now, pray take my advice and keep up your spirits.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: I will, Madam, Shaking hands with Placid. And do you keep up your spirits. Exeunt Mr. and Mrs. Placid. Irwin shuts the door with care after them, and looks round the room as if he feared to be seen or overheard. I am glad they are gone. I spoke unkindly to you just now, did I not? My temper is altered lately; and yet I love you.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I never doubted it, nor ever will.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: If you did, you would wrong me; for there is not a danger I would not risk for your sake; there is not an infamy I would not be branded with to make you happy, nor a punishment I would not undergo, with joy, for your welfare.—But there is a bar to this; we are unfortunately so entwined together, so linked, so rivetted, so cruelly, painfully fettered to each other, you could not be happy unless I shared the self same happiness with you. —But you will learn better—now you are in London, and amongst fashionable wives; you must learn better. Walks about and smiles, with a ghastly countenance.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Do not talk, do not look thus wildly—Indeed, indeed, you make me very uneasy.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p:
What! uneasy when I come to bring you comfort; and such comfort as you have not experienced
for many a day? He pulls out a pocket-book. Here is a friend in our necessity,—a friend that brings a thousand friends; plenty and—no, not always— peace. He takes several papers from the book, and puts them into her hands—She looks at them, then screams.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Ah! 'Tis money. Trembling. These are Bank notes.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Hush! For heaven's sake, hush! We shall be discovered. Trembling and in great perturbation. What alarms you thus?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: What alarms you?

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Do you say I am frightened?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: A sight so new has frightened me.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Nay, they are your own: by heaven, they are! No one on earth has a better, or a fairer right than you have. It was a laudable act by which I obtained them.—The parent-bird had forsook its young, and I but forced it back to perform the rites of nature.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: You are insane, I fear. No, no, I do not fear— hope you are.

div3.stage: A loud rapping at the street-door—He starts, takes the notes from her, and puts them hastily into his pocket.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Go to the door yourself; and if 'tis any one who asks for me, say I am not come home yet.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: It is the person belonging to the house: no one to us.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: My dear Eleanor, are you willing to quit London with me in about two hours time?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Instantly.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Nay, not only London, but England.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: This world, if you desire it. To go in company with you, will make the journey pleasant; and all I loved on earth would still be with me.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: You can, then, leave your father without regret, never, never to see him more?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Why should I think on him, who will not think of me?Weeps.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: But our children—

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: We are not to leave them behind?

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: One of them we must: but do not let that give you uneasiness. You know he has never lived with us since his infancy, and cannot pine for the loss of parents whom he has never known.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p:
But I have known him. He was my first; and, sometimes, I think more closely wound around my heart, than all the rest. The grief I felt on being forced to leave him when we went
abroad, and the constant anxiety I have since experienced lest he should not be kindly treated, have augmented, I think, my tenderness.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: All my endeavours to-day, as well as every other day, have been in vain to find into what part of the country his nurse has taken him.—Nay, be not thus overcome with tears; we will (in spite of all my haste to be gone) stay one more miserable day here, in hopes to procure intelligence, so as to take him with us; and then smile with contempt on all we leave behind. Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE I. A Library at Lord NORLAND's.
div3.stage: Enter Lord NORLAND, followed by Mr. HARMONY.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND,
sp.p: I TELL you, Mr. Harmony, that if an indifferent person, one on whom I had never bestowed a favour in my life, were to offend me, it is in my nature never to forgive. Can I then forgive my own daughter, my only child, on whom I heaped continually marks of the most affectionate fondness? Shall she dare to offend me in the tenderest point, and you dare to suppose I will pardon her?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Your child, consider.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: The weakest argument you can use. As my child, was not she most bound to obey me? As my child, ought she not to have sacrificed her own happiness to mine? Instead of which, mine has been yielded up for a whim, a fancy, a fancy to marry a beggar; and as such is her choice, let her beg with him.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: She does by me;—pleads hard for your forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p:
If I thought she dared to send a message to me, though dictated on her knees, she should find
that she had not yet felt the full force of my resentment.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: What could you do more?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I have done nothing yet. At present, I have only abandoned her;—but I can persecute.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I have no doubt of it: and, that I may not be the means of aggravating your displeasure, I assure you, that what I have now said has been entirely from myself, without any desire of hers; and, at the same time, I give you my promise, I will never presume to intrude the subject again.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: On this condition (but on no other) I forgive you now.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: And now then, my Lord, let us pass from those who have forfeited your love, to those who possess it.—I heard some time ago, but I never presumed to mention it to you, that you had adopted a young man as your son?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: "A young man!" Pshaw!—No; a boy—a mere child, who fell in my way by accident.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: A chance child! Ho! ho!—I understand you.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Do not jest with me, Sir. Do I look—

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Yes, you look as if you would be ashamed to own it, if you had one.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: But this boy I am not ashamed of:—he is a favourite—rather a favourite.—I did not like him so well at first;—but custom,—and having a poor creature entirely at one's mercy, one begins to love it merely from the idea of—What would be its fate if one did not?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Is he an orphan then?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: You have a friendship for his parents?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I never saw the father: his mother I had a friendship for once. Sighing.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Ay, while the husband was away?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I tell you, no. violently—But ask no more questions. Who his parents are, is a secret, which neither he, nor any one (that is now living) knows, except myself; nor ever shall.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Well, my Lord, since 'tis your pleasure to consider him as your child, I sincerely with you may experience more duty from him than you have done from your daughter.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Thank Heaven, his disposition is not in the least like her's.—No: very much impassioned I have the joy to say, that never child was so unlike its mother.

sp.speaker: HARMONY,
sp.p: How! His mother!

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Confusion!—what have I said?—I am ashamed—

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: No,—be proud.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: That you have a lawful heir to all your riches; proud that you have a grandson.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I would have concealed it from all the world; I wished it even unknown to myself. And let me tell you, Sir, (as not by my design, but through my inadvertency, you are become acquainted with this secret) that, if ever you breathe it to a single creature, the boy shall answer for it; for, were he known to be her's, though he were dearer to me than ever she was, I would turn him from my house, and cast him from my heart, as I have done her.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I believe you;—and in compassion to the child, give you my solemn promise never to reveal who he is. I have heard that those unfortunate parents left an infant behind when they went abroad, and that they now lament him as lost. Will you satisfy my curiosity, in what manner you sought and found him out?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p:
Do you suppose I searched for him? No;—he was forced upon me. A woman followed me, about eight years ago, in the fields adjoining to
my country seat, with a half-starved boy in her hand, and asked my charity for my grand-child: the impression of the word, made me turn round involuntarily; and casting my eyes upon him, I was rejoiced, not to find a feature of his mother's in all his face; and I began to feel something like pity for him. In short, he caught such fast hold by one of my fingers, that I asked him carelessly "if he would go home and live with me?" On which, he answered me so willingly "Yes," I took him at his word.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: And did never your regard for him, plead in his mother's behalf?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Never. For, by Heaven, I would as soon forgive the robber who met me last night at my own door, and, holding a pistol to my breast, took from me a sum to a considerable amount, as I would pardon her.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Did such an accident happen to you?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Have you not heard of it?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: It is amazing we cannot put a stop to such depredations.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Provisions are so scarce!

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Miss Wooburn, my Lord, if you are not engaged, will come and sit an hour with you.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I have no company but what she is perfectly acquainted with, and shall be glad of her visit.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: You forget I am a stranger, and my presence may not be welcome.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: A stranger! What, to my ward? to Lady Ramble? for that is the name which custom would authorise her to keep; but such courtesy she disdains, in contempt of the unworthy giver of the title.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I am intimate with Sir Robert, my Lord; and though I acknowledge that both you and his lady have cause for complaint, yet Sir Robert has still many virtues.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Not one. He is the most vile, the most detestable of characters. He not only contradicted my will in the whole of his conduct, but he seldom met me that he did not give me some personal affront.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: It is, however, generally held better to be uncivil in a person's presence, than in his absence.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: He was uncivil to me in every respect.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: That I will deny; for I have heard Sir Robert, in your absence, say such things in your praise!—

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Most assuredly.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I wish he had sometimes done me the honour to have spoken politely to my face.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: That is not Sir Robert's way;—he is no flatterer. But then, no sooner has your back been turned, than I have heard him lavish in your praise.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I must own, Mr. Harmony, that I never looked upon Sir Robert as incorrigible. I could always discern a ray of understanding, and a beam of virtue through all his foibles; nor would I have urged the divorce, but that I found his wife's sensibility could not bear his neglect; and even now, notwithstanding her endeavour to conceal it, she pines in secret, and laments her hard fortune. All my hopes of restoring her health rest on one prospect—that of finding a man worthy my recommendation for her second husband, and, by creating a second passion, expel the first.—Mr. Harmony, you and I have been long acquainted—I have known your disposition from your infancy— Now, if such a man as you were to offer—

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: You flatter me.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I do not.—Would you venture to become her husband?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I cannot say I have any particular desire; but if it will oblige either you or her,—for my part, I think the short time we live in this world, we should do all we can to oblige each other.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p:
I should rejoice at such an union myself, and I
think I can answer for her.—You permit me then to make overtures to her in your name?

sp.speaker: HARMONY,
sp.p: This is rather a serious piece of business— However, I never did make a difficulty when I wished to oblige a friend.—But there is one proviso, my Lord; I must first mention it to Sir Robert.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Because he and I have always been very intimate friends; and to marry his wife, without even telling him of it, will appear very uncivil!

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Do you mean then to ask his consent?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Not absolutely his consent; but I will insinuate the subject to him, and obtain his approbation in a manner suitable to my own satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: You will oblige me then if you will see him as early as possible; for it is reported he is going abroad.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I will go to him immediately;—and, my Lord, I will do all in my power to oblige you, Sir Robert and the Lady; aside—but as to obliging myself, that was never one of my considerations.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p:
I am sorry to see you thus; you have been weeping? Will you still lament your separation from a
cruel husband, as if you had followed a kind one to the grave?

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: By no means, my Lord. Tears from our sex are not always the result of grief; they are frequently no more than little sympathetic tributes which we pay to our fellow-beings, while the mind and the heart are steeled against the weakness which our eyes indicate.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Can you say, your mind and heart are so steeled?

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: I can: My mind is as firmly fixed against Sir Robert Ramble, as at our first acquaintance it was fixed upon him. And I solemnly protest—

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: To a man of my age and observation, protestations are vain.—Give me a proof that you have rooted him from your heart.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Any proof you require, I will give without a moment's hesitation.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I take you at your word; and desire you to accept a Gentleman, whom I shall recommend for your second husband. Miss Wooburn starts— You said you would not hesitate a moment.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: I thought I should not;—but this is something. so unexpected—

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: You break your word then, and still give cause for this ungrateful man, to ridicule your fondness for him.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: No, I will put an end to that humiliation; and whoever the Gentleman is whom you mean to propose—Yet, do not name him at present—but give me the satisfaction of keeping the promise I have made to you (at least for a little time) without exactly knowing how far it extends; for, in return, I have a promise to ask from you, before I acquaint you with the nature of your engagement.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I give my promise. Now name your request.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Then, my Lord, hesitating and confused—the law gave me back, upon my divorce from Sir Robert, the very large fortune which I brought to him.—I am afraid, that in his present circumstances, to enforce the strict payment of this debt, would very much embarrass him.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: What if it did?

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: It is my entreaty to you (in whose hands is invested the power to demand this right of law) to lay my claim aside for the present. Lord Norland offers to speak I know, my Lord, what you are going to say; I know Sir Robert is not now, but I can never forget that he has been my husband.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p:
To shew my gratitude for your compliance with the request I have just made you, Goes to a table in the library here is the bond by which I am impowered to seize on the greatest part of his estates in right of you: take the bond into your own possession till your next husband demands it
of you; and by the time you have called him husband for a few weeks, this tenderness, or delicacy to Sir Robert, will be worn away.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: My Lord, I beg pardon; but I forgot to mention—

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Harmony, I have not seen you before I know not when: I am particularly happy at your calling just now, for I have— hesitating a little favour to ask of you.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: If it were a great favour, Madam, you might command me.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: But—my Lord, I beg your pardon—but the favour I have to ask of Mr. Harmony must be told to him in private.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Oh! I am sure I have not the least objection to you and Mr. Harmony having a private conference. I'll leave you together. Harmony appears embarrassed. You do not derange my business— I'll be back in a short time. Exit.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Mr. Harmony, you are the very man on earth I most wanted to see. Harmony bows. I know the kindness of your heart, the liberality of your sentiments, and I wish to repose a charge to your trust, very near to me indeed—but you must be secret.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: When a Lady reposes a trust in me, I should not be a man if I were not.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: I must first inform you, that Lord Norland has just drawn from me a promise, that I will once more enter into the marriage-state; and without knowing to whom he intends to give me, I will keep my promise—But it is in vain to say, that, though I mean all duty and fidelity to my second husband, I shall not experience moments when my thoughts—will wander on my first.

sp.speaker: HARMONY,
sp.p: Hem!—Hem!— To her—Indeed?

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: I must always rejoice in Sir Robert's successes, and lament over his misfortunes.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: If that is all—

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: No, I would go one step further: Harmony starts again I would secure him from those misfortunes, which to hear of, will disturb my peace of mind. I know his fortune has suffered very much, and I cannot, will not, place it in the power of the man, whom my Lord Norland may point out for my next marriage, to distress him farther. —This is the writing, by which that Gentleman may claim the part of my fortune from Sir Robert Ramble, which is in landed property; carry it, my dear Mr. Harmony, to Sir Robert instantly; and tell him, that in separating from him, I meant only to give him liberty; not make him the debtor, perhaps the prisoner of my future husband.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Madam, I will most undoubtedly take this bond to my friend; but will you give me leave to suggest to you, that the person on whom you bestow your hand, may be a little surprised to find, that while he is in possession of you, Sir Robert is in the possession of your fortune?

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Do not imagine, Sir, that I shall marry any man, without first declaring what I have done—I only wish at present it should be concealed from Lord Norland—When this paper is given, as I have required, it cannot be recalled; and when that is past, I shall divulge my conduct to whom I please; and first of all, to him, who shall offer me his addresses.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: And if he is a man of my feelings, his addresses will be doubly importunate for this proof of liberality to your former husband. — But are you sure, that in the return of this bond, there is no secret affection, no latent spark of love?

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: None. I know my heart; and if there was, I could not ask you, Mr. Harmony (nor any one like you), to be the messenger of an imprudent passion. Sir Robert's vanity, I know, may cause him to judge otherwise; but undeceive him; let him know this is a sacrifice to the golden principles of duty, and not an offering to the tinselled shrine of love. Enter Lord NORLAND. Put up the bond.— Harmony conceals it.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Well, my dear, have you made your request?

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: And has he granted it?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord. I am going to grant it.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I sincerely wish you both joy of this good understanding between you. But, Mr. Harmony, in a whisper are not you going to Sir Robert?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I am going this moment.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Make haste then, and do not forget your errand.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I sha'n't forget my errand; it won't slip my memory—Good morning, my Lord —good morning, Madam. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Now, my dear, as you and Mr. Harmony seem, to be on such excellent terms, I think I may venture to tell you (if he has not yet told you himself), that he is the man, who is to be your husband.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: He! Mr. Harmony!—No, my Lord, he has not told me; and I am confident he never will.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: What makes you think so?

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Because—because—he must be sensible he would not be the man I should choose.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: And where is the woman who marries the man she would choose? You are reversing the order of society; men, only, have the right of choice in marriage. Were women permitted theirs, we should have handsome beggars allied to our noblest families, and no such object in our whole island as an old maid.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: But being denied that choice, why forbid to remain as I am?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: What are you now? Neither a widow, a maid, nor a wife. If I could fix a term to your present state, I should not be thus anxious to place you in another.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: I am perfectly acquainted with your friendly motives, and feel the full force of your advice.— I therefore renew my promise—and although Mr. Harmony (in respect to the marriage state) is as little to my wishes as any man on earth, I will nevertheless endeavour—whatever struggles it may cost me—to be to him, if he prefers his suit, a dutiful, an obedient—but, for a loving wife, that I can never be again.

div3.head: SCENE, An Apartment at Sir RORBERT RAMBLE's.
div3.stage: Enter Sir ROBERT and Mr. HARMONY.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I thank you for this visit. I was undetermined what to do with myself. Your company has determined me to stay at home.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I was with a Gentleman just now, Sir Robert, and you were the subject of our conversation.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Had it been a Lady, I should be anxious to know what she said.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I have been with a Lady likewise; and she made you the subject of her discourse.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: But was she handsome?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Very handsome.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: My dear fellow, what is her name? What did she say, and where may I meet with her?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Her name is Wooburn.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: That is the name of my late wife.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: It is her I mean.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Zounds, you had just put my spirits into a flame, and now you throw cold water all over me.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I am sorry to hear you say so, for I came from her this moment; and what do you think is the present she has given me to deliver to you?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Pshaw! I want no presents. Some of my old love-letters returned, I suppose, to remind me of my inconstancy?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Do not undervalue her generosity: this is her present;—this bond, which has power to take from you three thousand a year, her right.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Ah! this is a present indeed. Are you sure you speak truth? Let me look at it:—Sure my eyes deceive me!—No, by Heaven it is true! Reads The very thing I wanted, and will make me perfectly happy. Now I'll be generous again; my bills shall be paid, my gaming debts cancelled, poor Irwin shall find a friend; and I'll send her as pretty a copy of verses as ever I wrote in my life.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Take care how you treat with levity a woman of her elevated mind. She charged me to assure you, "that love had no share whatever in this act, but merely compassion to the embarrassed state of your affairs."

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Sir, I would have you to know, I am no object of compassion. However, a Lady's favour one cannot return; and so, I'll keep this thing.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Nay, if your circumstances are different from what she imagines, give it me back, and I will return it to her.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p:
No, poor thing! it would break her heart to send it back—No, I'll keep it—She would never forgive me, were I to send it back. I'll keep it. And she is welcome to attribute her concern for me to what she pleases. But surely you can see— you can understand—But Heaven bless her for
her love! and I would love her in return—if I could.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: You would not talk thus, if you had seen the firm dignity with which she gave me that paper— "Assure him," said she, "no remaining affection comes along with it, but merely a duty which I owe him, to protect him from the humiliation of being a debtor to the man whom I am going to marry."

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.p: Why, she is not going to be married again!

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I believe so.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: But are you sure of it, Sir? Are you sure of it?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Both she and her guardian told me so.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: That guardian, my Lord Norland, is one of the basest, vilest of men.—I tell you what, Sir, I'll resent this usage.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Wherefore?—As to his being the means of bringing about your separation, in that he obliged you.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, he did, he certainly did;—but though I am not the least offended with him on that head (for at that I rejoice), yet I will resent his disposing of her a second time.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: And why?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Because, little regard as I have for her myself, yet no other man shall dare to treat her so ill, as I have done.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Do not fear it—Her next husband will be a man, who, I can safely say, will never insult, or even offend her; but sooth, indulge, and make her happy.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And do you dare to tell me, that her next husband shall make her happy? Now, that is worse than the other—No, Sir, no man shall ever have it to say "he has made her either happy or miserable," but myself.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I know of but one way to prevent it.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And what is that?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Pay your addresses to her, and marry her again yourself.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And I would, rather than she should be happy with any body else. The devil take me if I would not.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: To shew that I am wholly disinterested in this affair, I will carry her a letter from you if you like, and say all I can in your behalf.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Now, my dear Harmony, you carry your good-natured simplicity too far. However, I thank you, I sincerely thank you—But do you imagine I should be such a blockhead, as to make love to the same woman I made love to seven years ago, and who for the last six years I totally neglected?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Yes: for if you neglected her six years, she will now be a novelty.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Egad, and so she will. You are right.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: But being in possession of her fortune, you can be very happy without her.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Take her fortune back, Sir. Taking the bond from his pocket and offering it to Harmony I would starve, I would perish, die in poverty and infamy, rather than owe an obligation to a vile, perfidious, inconstant woman.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Consider, Sir Robert, if you insist on my taking this bond back, it may fall into the husband's hands.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Take it back—I insist upon it. Gives it him, and Harmony puts it up But, Mr. Harmony, depend on it, Lord Norland shall hear from me, in the most serious manner, for his interference—I repeat, he is the vilest, the most villanous of men.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: How can you speak with such rancour of a nobleman, who speaks of you in the highest terms?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Does he, 'faith?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: He owns you have some faults.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I know I have.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: But he thinks your good qualities are numberless.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p:
Now dam'me, if ever I thought so ill of him, as I have appeared to do!—But who is the intended
husband, my dear friend? Tell me, that I may laugh at him, and make you laugh at him.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: No, I am not inclined to laugh at him.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Is it old Solus?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: But I will bet you a wager it is somebody equally ridiculous.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I never bet.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Solus is mad for a wife, and has been praising mine up to the heavens; you need say no more; I know it is he.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Upon my honour, it is not. However, I cannot disclose to you at present the person's name; I must first obtain Lord Norland's permission.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I shall ask you no more. I'll write to her— she will tell me;—or, I'll pay her a visit, and ask her boldly myself.—Do you think anxiously—do you think she would see me?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: You can but try.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Mr. Solus.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Now I will find out the secret immediately.—I'll charge him with being the intended husband.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I will not stay to hear you. Enter SOLUS. Mr. Solus, how do you do? I am extremely sorry that my enagagements take me away as soon as you enter. Exit Harmony running, to avoid an explanation.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Sir Robert, what is the matter? Has any thing ruffled you? Why, I never saw you look more out of temper, even while you were married.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Ah! that I had never married! never known what marriage was! for, even at this moment, I feel its torments in my heart.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I have often heard of the torments of matrimony; but I conceive, that at the worst, they are nothing more than a kind of violent tickling, which will force the tears into your eyes, though at the same time you are bursting your sides with laughter.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: You have defined marriage too favourably; there is no laughter in the state: all is melancholy, all gloom.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Now I think marriage is an excellent remedy for the spleen. I have known a Gentleman at a feast receive an affront, disguise his rage, step home, vent it all upon his wife, return to his companions, and be as good company as if nothing had happened.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: But even the necessary expences of a wife should alarm you.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I can then retrench some of my own.
