Oh! my dear Sir, a married man has so many delightful privileges to what a bachelor has!—An old Lady will introduce her daughters to you in a dishabille —"It does not signify, my dears, it's a married man"—One Lady will suffer you to draw on her glove—"Never mind, it's a married man"— Another will permit you to pull on her slipper; a third will even take you into her bed-chamber —"Pshaw, it's nothing but a married man."

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: But the weight of your fetters will overbalance all these joys.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: And I cannot say, notwithstanding you are relieved from the bond, that I see much joy or brightness here.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I am not very well at present; I have the headach; and, if ever a wife can be of comfort to her husband, it must be when he is indisposed. A wife, then, binds up your head, mixes your powders, bathes your temples, and hovers about, in a way that is most endearing.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Don't speak of it; I long to have one hover about me. But I will—I am determined I will, before I am a week older. Don't speak, don't attempt to persuade me not. Your description has renewed my eagerness—I will be married.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p:
And without pretending not to know who you mean to make your wife, I tell you plainly, it is, Miss Wooburn, it is my late wife.—I know you
made overtures to my Lord Norland, and that he has given his consent.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: You tell me a great piece of news—I'll go ask my Lord if it be true; and if he says it is, I shall be very glad to find it so.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: That is right, Sir; marry her, marry her;—I give you joy,—that's all.—Ha, ha, ha! I think I should know her temper.—But if you will venture to, marry her, I sincerely wish you happy.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: And if we are not, you know we can be divorced.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Not always. Take my advice, and live as you are.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: You almost stagger my resolution.—I had painted such bright prospects in marriage:—Good day to you. Going, returns—You think I had better not marry?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: You are undone if you do.

sp.speaker: SOLUS,
sp.p: You ought to know from experience.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: From that I speak.

sp.speaker: SOLUS,
sp.stage: Going to the door, and returning once or twice, as unstable in his resolution.
sp.p:
But then, what a poor disconsolate object shall I live, without a wife to hover about me; to bind up my head, and bathe my temples! Oh! I am
impatient for all the chartered rights, privileges, and immunities of a married man. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Furies, racks, torments—I cannot bear what I feel, and yet I am ashamed to own I feel any thing!

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: My dear Sir Robert, give me joy. Mrs. Placid and I are come to the very point you advised; matters are in the fairest way for a separation.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I do give you joy, and most sincerely.—You are right; you'll soon be as happy as I am. Sighing But would you suppose it? that deluded woman, my wife, is going to be married again! I thought she had had enough of me!

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: You are hurt, I see, lest the world should say she has forgot you.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: She cannot forget me; I defy her to forget me.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Who is her intended husband?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Solus, Solus. An old man—an ugly man. He left me this moment, and owned it—owned it! Go after him, will you, and persuade him not to have her.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: My advice will have no effect, for you know he is bent upon matrimony.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Then could not you, my dear Sir (as you are going to be separated), could not you recommend him to marry your wife?—It will be all the same to him, I dare say, and I shall like it much better.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Ours will not be a divorce, consider, but merely a separate maintenance. But were it otherwise, I wish no man so ill, as to wish him married to Mrs. Placid.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: That is my case exactly. I wish no man so ill, as to wish him married to my Lady Ramble; and poor old Solus in particular, poor old man! a very good sort of man—I have a great friendship for Solus.—I can't stay a moment in the house—I must go somewhere—I'll go to Solus.—No, I'll go to Lord Norland—No, I will go to Harmony; and then I'll call on you, and we'll take a bottle together; and when we are both free takes his hand we'll join, from that moment we'll join, to laugh at, to contemn, to despise all those who boast of the joys of conjugal love. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: AND now, for one of the most painful tasks that brotherly love ever draws upon me; to tell another, the suit, of which I gave him hope, has failed.—Yet, if I can but overcome Captain Irwin's delicacy so far, as to prevail on him to accept one proof more of my good wishes towards him;— but to a man of his nice sense of obligations, the offer must be made with caution.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Mr. Harmony, I beg your pardon: I come in thus abruptly, from the anxiety I feel concerning what passed between us this morning in respect to Miss Wooburn. You have not changed your mind, I hope?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lord, I am very sorry that it will not be in my power to oblige you.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND,
sp.p: How, Sir? Did not you give me your word?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Only conditionally, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: And what were the conditions?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Have you forgot them? Her former husband.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Sir Robert Ramble is in his carriage at the door, and, if you are at leisure, will come in.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Desire him to walk up. I have your leave, I suppose, my Lord?Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Yes; but let me get out of the house without meeting him. Going to the opposite door Can I go this way?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Why should you shun him?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Because he used his wife ill.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: He did. But I believe he is very sorry for it. —And as for you, he said to me only a few hours ago—but no matter.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: What did he say? I insist upon knowing.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Why then he said, "that if he had a sacred trust to repose in any one, you should be the man on earth, to whom he would confide it."

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Well, I am in no hurry; I can stay a few minutes.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p:
Oh! Harmony! I am in such a distracted state
of mind— Seeing Lord Norland, he starts, and bows with the most humble respect.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Sir Robert, how do you do?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: My Lord, I am pretty well.—I hope I have the happiness of seeing your Lordship in perfect health.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lord, I think I never saw you look better.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Mr. Harmony, you and Sir Robert may have some business—I'll wish you a good morning.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I fancy Sir Robert has nothing particular.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing, I assure you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: However, I have business myself in another place, and so you will excuse me. Going.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.p: My Lord—Lord Norland,—I trust you will excuse my enquiries.—I hope, my Lord, all your family are well?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: All very well.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p:
Your little Elevè,—Master Edward,—the young Gentleman you have adopted—I hope he is
well— hesitating and confused And—your Ward, Sir—Miss Wooburn—I hope, my Lord, she is well?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Yes, Sir Robert, Miss Wooburn is tolerably well.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Only tolerably, my Lord? I am sorry for that.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I hope, my Lord, you will excuse my mentioning the subject; but I was telling Sir Robert just now, of your intentions respecting a second marriage for that Lady; but Sir Robert does not appear to approve of the design.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: What objection can he have?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: My Lord, there are such a number of bad husbands; there are such a number of dissipated, unthinking, unprincipled men!—And—I should be extremely sorry to see any Lady with whom I have had the honour of being so closely allied, united to one who would undervalue her worth.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Pray, Sir Robert, were you not then extremely sorry for her, while she was united to you?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Very sorry for her indeed, my Lord. But, at that time, my mind was so taken up with other cares, I own I did not feel the compassion which was her due; but, now that I am single, I shall have leisure to pay her more attention; and should I find her unhappy, it must, inevitably, make me so.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Depend upon it, that on the present occasion, I shall take infinite care in the choice of her husband.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: If your Lordship would permit me to have an interview with Miss Wooburn, I think I should be able at least—

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: You would not sure insult her by your presence?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I think I should be able at least to point out an object worthy of her taste—I know what she will like better than any body in the world.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Her request has been, that I may point her out a husband the reverse of you.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Then, upon my honour, my Lord, she won't like him.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Have not you liked women the reverse of her?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, perhaps I have, and perhaps I still do. I do not pretend to love her; I did not say I did; nay, I positively protest I do not; but this indifference I acknowledge as one of my faults; and, notwithstanding all my faults, give me leave to acknowledge my gratitude that your Lordship has nevertheless been pleased to declare you think my virtues are numberless. Lord Norland shews surprise.

sp.speaker: HARMONY,
sp.p: Hush, hush!—Don't, talk of your virtues now.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Sir Robert, to all this incoherent language, this is my answer, this is my will: The Lady, to whom I have had the honour to be guardian, shall never (while she calls me friend) see you more.

div3.stage: Sir ROBERT, at this sentence, stands silent for some time, then, suddenly recollecting himself

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Lord Norland, I am too well acquainted with the truth of your word, and the firmness of your temper, to press my suit one sentence farther.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I commend your discernment.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: My Lord, I feel myself a little embarrassed.— I am afraid I have made myself a little ridiculous upon this occasion—Will your Lordship do me the favour to forget it?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I will forget whatever you please.

sp.speaker: HARMONY
sp.p: I am sorry to see you going away in despair.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I never did despair in my life, Sir; and while a woman is the object of my wishes, I never will.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: What did he say?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: That he thought your conduct that of a just and an upright man.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p:
To say the truth, he has gone away with better
manners than I could have imagined, considering his jealousy is provoked.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Ah! I always knew he loved his wife, notwithstanding his behaviour to her; for, if you remember, he always spoke well of her behind her back.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: No, I do not remember it.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Yes, he did; and that is the only criterion of a man's love, or of his friendship.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: A young gentleman is at the door, Sir, enquiring for Lord Norland.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Who can it be?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Your young gentleman from home, I dare say. Desire him to walk in. Bring him here.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: What business can he have to follow me?

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Oh, my Lord, I beg your pardon for coming hither; but I come to tell you something you will be glad to hear.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Good Heaven! how like his mother!

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND,
sp.p: I begin to think he is—but he was not so when I first took him. No, no, if he had, he would not have been thus near me now;—but to turn him away because his countenance is a little changed, I think would not be right.

sp.speaker: EDWARD,
sp.p: Pray, Sir, did you know my mother?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I have seen her.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Did you ever see her, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I thought you had orders never to enquire about your parents? Have you forgot those orders?

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: No, my Lord; but when this gentleman said I was like my mother—it put me in mind of her.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: You do not remember your mother, do you?

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Sometimes I think I do. I think sometimes I remember her kissing me, when she and my father went on board of a ship; and so hard she pressed me—I think I feel it now.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Perhaps she was the only Lady that ever saluted you?

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: No, Sir; not by many.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p:
But pray, young man (to have done with this
subject), what brought you here? You seem to have forgot your errand?

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: And so I had, upon my word. Speaking of my mother, put it quite out of my head.—But, my Lord, I came to let you know, the robber who stopped you last night is taken.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I am glad to hear it.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: I knew you would; and therefore I begged to be the first to tell you.

sp.speaker: HARMONY,
sp.p: Should you know the person again?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I cannot say I should, his face seemed so much distorted.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Ay, wretched man! I suppose with terror.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: No; it appeared a different passion from fear.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Perhaps, my Lord, it was your fear that made you think so.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: No, Sir, I was not frightened.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Then why did you give him your money?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: It was surprise caused me to do that.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: I wondered what it was! You said it was not fear, and I was sure it could not be love.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: How has he been taken?

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: A person came to our steward, and informed against him;—and, Oh! my Lord, his poor wife told the officers who took him, they had met with misfortunes, which she feared had caused a fever in her husband's head; and, indeed, they found him too ill to be removed; and so, she hoped, she said, "that as a man, not in his perfect mind, you would be merciful to him."

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I will be just.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: And that is being merciful, is it not, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Not always.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: I thought it had been.—It is not just to be unmerciful, is it?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Then it must be just, to have mercy.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: You draw a false conclusion. Great as is the virtue of mercy, justice is greater still. Justice holds its place among those cardinal virtues which include all the lesser.—Come, Mr. Harmony, will you go home with me? And before I attend to this business, let me persuade you to forget there is such a person in the world as Sir Robert, and suffer me to introduce you to Miss Wooburn, as the man who—

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I beg to be excused—Besides the consideration of Sir Robert, I have another reason why I cannot go with you. The melancholy tale which this young gentleman has been telling, has cast a gloom on my spirits which renders me unfit for the society of a Lady.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Now I should not be surprised were you to go in search of this culprit and his family, and come to me to intreat me to forego the prosecution; but, before you ask me, I tell you it is in vain—I will not.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Lord Norland, I have lately been so unsuccessful in my petitions to you, I shall never presume to interpose between your rigour and a weak sufferer more.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Plead the cause of the good, and I will listen; but you find none but the wicked for your compassion.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: The good in all states, even in the very jaws of death, are objects of envy; it is the bad who are the only real sufferers: There, where no internal consolation cheers, who can refuse a little external comfort?—And let me tell you, my Lord, that amidst all your authority, your state, your grandeur, I often pity you. Speaking with unaffected compassion.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Good-day, Mr. Harmony; and when you have apologised for what you have said, we may be friends again. Exit, leading off Edward.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Nay, hear my apology now. I cannot—no, it is not in my nature to live in resentment, nor under the resentment of any creature in the world.

div3.stage: Enter Sir ROBERT RAMBLE, followed by a Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Do not say who it is—but say a Gentleman who has some very particular business with her.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. Going.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Pray, Servant returns You are but lately come into this service, I believe?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Only a few days, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: You don't know me, then?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I am very glad of it. So much the better. Go to Miss Wooburn, with a Stranger's compliments who is waiting, and who begs to speak with her upon an affair of importance.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p:
I wish I may die if I don't feel very unaccountably! How different are our sensations towards
our wives, and all other women! This is the very first time she has given me a palpitation since the honey-moon.

div3.stage: Enter Miss WOOBURN, who starts on seeing Sir Robert;—he bows in great confusion.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Support me, Heaven!Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.stage: Bows repeatedly, and does not speak till after many efforts.
sp.p: Was ever man in such confusion before his wife!Aside.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Sir Robert, having recovered in some measure, from the surprise into which this intrusion first threw me, I have only to say, that whatever pretence may have induced you to offer me this insult, there are none to oblige me to bear with it.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Lady Ramb— recalling himself Miss Woo— She turns Lady Ramble— recalling himself again Miss Wooburn—Madam—You wrong me— There was a time when I insulted you, I confess; but it is impossible that time should ever return.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: While I stay with you, I incur the danger.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.p: Nay, listen to me as a friend, whom you have so often heard as an enemy.—You offered me a favour by the hands of Mr. Harmony—

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: And is this the motive of your visit—this the return—

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: No, Madam, that obligation was not the motive which drew me hither—The real cause of this seeming intrusion is—you are going to be married once more, and I come to warn you of your danger.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: That you did sufficiently in the marriage-state.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: But now I come to offer you advice that may be of the most material consequence, should you really be determined to yield yourself again into the power of a husband.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Which I most assuredly am.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Happy, happy man! How much is he the object of my envy! None so well as I, know how to envy him, because none so well as I, know how to value you. She offers to go Nay, by Heaven you shall not go till you have heard all that I came to say!

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Speak it then instantly.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: No, it would take whole ages to speak; and should we live together, as long as we have lived together, still I should not find time to tell you— how much I love you.

div3.stage: A loud rapping at the street-door.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: That, I hope, is Lord Norland.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p:
And what has Lord Norland to do with souls
free as ours? Let us go to Scotland again; and again bid defiance to his stern commands.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Be assured, that through him only, will I ever listen to a syllable you have to utter.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: One syllable only, and I am gone that instant.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Well, Sir?

div3.stage: He hesitates, trembles, seems to struggle with himself; then approaching her slowly, timidly, and as if ashamed of his humiliation, kneels to her— She turns away.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.p: Maria, Maria, look at me!—Look at me in this humble state—Could you have suspected this, Maria?

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: No: nor can I conceive what this mockery means.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: It means, that now you are no longer my wife, you are my Goddess; and thus I offer you my supplication, that (if you are resolved not to live single) amongst the numerous train who present their suit, you will once more select me.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: You!—You who have treated me with cruelty; who made no secret of your love for others—but gloried, boasted of your gallantries?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p:
I did, I did—But here I swear, only trust me again—do but once more trust me, and I swear
by all I hold most sacred, that I will for the future carefully conceal all my gallantries from your knowledge—though they were ten times more frequent than before.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Oh, my dear Miss Wooburn—What! Sir Robert here too! Goes to Sir Robert and shakes hands How do you do, Sir Robert? Who would have thought of seeing you here? I am glad to see you though, with all my heart; and so I dare say is Miss Wooburn, though she may not like to say so.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: You are impertinent, Sir.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: What, for coming in? I will go away then.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Do, do—There's a good boy—do.

sp.speaker: EDWARD,
sp.p: I cannot help laughing, though, to see you two together!—For you know you never were together when you lived in the same house.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Leave the room instantly, Sir, or I shall call Lord Norland.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Oh, don't take that trouble, I will call him myself. Runs to the door—My Lord, my Lord, pray come here this moment—As I am alive, here is Sir Robert Ramble along with Lady Ramble!

div3.stage: Sir Robert looks confounded, Lord Norland points to Edward to leave the room.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Sir Robert, on what pretence do you come hither?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: On the same pretence, as when I was for the first time admitted into your house; to solicit this Lady's hand. And, after having had it once, no force shall compel me to take a refusal.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I will try however—Madam, quit the room instantly.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: My Lord, she shall not quit it.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I command her to go.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And I command her to stay.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Which of us will you obey?

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: My inclination, my Lord, disposes me to obey you;—but I have so lately been accustomed to obey him, that custom inclines me to obey him still.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: There! There! There, my Lord! Now I hope you will understand better for the future, and not attempt to interfere between a man and his wife.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND,
sp.p: Be explicit in your answer to this question— Will you consent to be his wife?

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: No, never.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Zounds, my Lord, now you are hurrying matters.—You should do it by gentle means;—let me ask her gently. With a most soft voice Maria, Maria, will you be my wife once again?

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: So you said seven years ago when I asked you, and yet you consented.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: And now, Sir Robert, you have had your answer; leave my house. Going up to him.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; but not without my other half.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: "Your other half?"

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Yes; the wife of my bosom—the wife, whom I swore at the altar to love and to cherish, and, forsaking all others, cleave only to her as long as we both should live.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: You broke your oath, and made the contract void.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: But I am ready to take another oath; and another after that, and another after that—And, Oh, my dear Maria, be propitious to my vows, and give me hopes you will again be mine. He goes to her, and kneels in the most supplicating attitude.

div3.stage: Enter EDWARD, shewing in Mr. SOLUS and Mr. PLACID; Edward points to Sir Robert (who has his back to them) and goes off.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.stage: Still on his knees, and not perceiving their entrance.
sp.p: I cannot live without you.—Receive your penitent husband, thus humbly acknowledging his faults, and imploring you to accept him once again.

sp.speaker: SOLUS,
sp.p: Now, is it wonderful that I should want a wife?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: And is it to be wondered at, if I should hesitate about parting with mine?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT
sp.p: Mr. Solus, Mr. Placid, I am highly displeased that my private actions should be thus inspected.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: No one shall persuade me now, to live a day without a wife.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: And no one shall persuade me now, not to be content with my own.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I will procure a special licence, and marry the first woman I meet.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Mr. Solus, you are, I believe, interested in a peculiar manner, about the marriage of this Lady.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p:
And, poor man, you are sick, and want somebody
to "bathe your temples," and to hover about you.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: You come in most opportunely, my dear Mr. Solus, to be a witness—

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: "My dear Mr. Solus!"

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: To be a witness, Madam, that a man is miserable without a wife. I have been a fatal instance of that, for some time.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Come to me then, and receive a lesson.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: No, Madam, he shall not come to you; nor shall he receive a lesson. No one shall receive a lesson from you, but me.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Sir Robert, one would suppose by this extraordinary behaviour, you were jealous.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And so I am, my Lord; I have cause to be so.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: No cause to be jealous of Mr. Solus—He is not Miss Wooburn's lover, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Then, my Lord, I verily believe it is yourself. Yes, I can see it is; I can see it by her eyes, and by every feature in your face.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Oh! my good friend, Mr. Placid, only listen to him.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And why "my good friend, Mr. Placid?" To Placid. By Heavens, Sir, I believe that you only wished to get rid of your own wife, in order to marry mine.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: I do not wish to part with my own wife, Sir Robert, since what I have just seen.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.stage: Going up to Solus and Lord Norland.
sp.p: Then, pray, gentlemen, be so good as to tell me, which of you two is the happy man, that I may know how to conduct myself towards him?

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Do you insult me, Maria?—Oh! have pity on my sufferings.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: If you have a mind to kneel down again, we will go out of the room.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Just as I was comforting myself with the prospect of a divorce, I find my instructor and director pleading on his knees to be remarried.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: What were you saying about a divorce?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Now, down on your knees, and beg pardon.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: My dear Mrs. Placid, if this visit is to me, I take it very kind.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Not absolutely to you, my dear. I saw Mr. Placid's carriage at the door, and so I stepped in to desire him to go home. Go home directly.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Presently, my dear; I will go presently.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Presently won't do; I say directly. There is a lady at my house in the greatest possible distress whispers him—Lady Eleanor—I never saw a creature in such distraction; Raising her voice —therefore go home this moment; you sha'n't stay an instant longer.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Egad, I don't know whether I will marry or no.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Why don't you go, Mr. Placid, when I bid you?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: No;—I think I won't marry.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: But, my dear, will not you go home with me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Did not I tell you to go by yourself?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: No;—I am sure I won't marry.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: And now, Mr. Solus and Sir Robert, these ladies may have some private conversation. Do me the favour to leave them alone.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p:
My Lord, with your leave we will retire. Turns
when she gets to the door. Sir Robert, I have remained in your company, and compelled myself to the painful task of hearing all you have had to say, merely for the satisfaction of exposing your love, and then enjoying the triumph of bidding you farewell for ever. Exit with Mrs. Placid.

sp.speaker: SOLUS,
sp.p: He turns pale at the thoughts of losing her. Yes, I think I'll marry.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Come, Sir Robert, it is in vain to loiter; your doom is fixed.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.p: Shall I then never again know what it is to have a heart like her's, to repose my troubles on?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Yes, I am pretty sure I'll marry.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: —A friend in all my anxieties, a companion in all my pleasures, a physician in all my sicknesses—

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Yes, I will marry.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Come, come, Sir Robert, do not let you and I have any dispute. Leading him towards the door.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Senseless man, not to value those blessings—Not to know how to estimate them, till they were lost.

sp.speaker: SOLUS,
sp.p: Yes,—I am determined;—nothing shall prevent me—I will be married. Exit.

div3.stage: Enter HAMMOND, followed by Lady ELEANOR.

sp.speaker: HAMMOND.
sp.p: MY Lord is busily engaged, Madam; I do not suppose he would see any one, much less a stranger.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I am no stranger.

sp.speaker: HAMMOND.
sp.p: Your name then, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: That, I cannot send in. But tell him, Sir, I am the afflicted wife of a man, who for some weeks past has given many fatal proofs of a disordered mind. In one of those fits of phrensy, he held an instrument of death, meant for his own destruction, to the breast of your Lord (who by accident that moment passed), and took from him, what he vainly hoped might preserve his own life, and relieve the wants of his family. But his paroxysm over, he shrunk from what he had done, and gave the whole he had thus unwarrantably taken, into a servant's hands to be returned to its lawful owner. The man, admitted to this confidence, betrayed his trust, and instead of giving up what was so sacredly delivered to him, secreted it; and, to obtain the promised reward, came to this house, but to inform against the wretched offender; who now, only resting on your Lord's clemency, can escape the direful fate he has incurred.

sp.speaker: HAMMOND.
sp.p: Madam, the account you give, makes me interested in your behalf, and you may depend, I will repeat it all with the greatest exactness.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR,
sp.p: This is my father's house! It is only through two rooms and one short passage, and there he is sitting in his study. Oh! in that study, where I (even in the midst of all his business) have been so often welcome; where I have urged the suit of many an unhappy person, nor ever urged in vain. Now I am not permitted to speak for myself, nor have one friendly voice to do that office for me, which I have so often undertaken for others.

sp.speaker: HAMMOND.
sp.p: My Lord says, that any petition concerning the person you come about, is in vain. His respect for the laws of his country demands an example such as he means to make.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Am I, am I to despair then? To Hammond Dear Sir, would you go once more to him, and humbly represent—

sp.speaker: HAMMOND.
sp.p: I should be happy to oblige you, but I dare not take any more messages to my Lord; he has given me my answer.—If you will give me leave, Madam, I'll see you to the door.

div3.stage: Crosses to the other side, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p:
Misery—Distraction!—Oh, Mr. Placid! Oh,
Mr. Harmony! Are these the hopes you gave me, could I have the boldness to enter this house? But you would neither of you undertake to bring me here!—neither of you undertake to speak for me!

div3.stage: She is following the Servant; Edward walks softly after her, till she gets near the door; he then takes hold of her gown, and gently pulls it; she turns and looks at him.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Shall I speak for you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Who are you, pray, young Gentleman? Is it you, whom Lord Norland has adopted for his son?

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: I believe he has, Madam; but he has never told me so yet.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I am obliged to you for your offer; but my suit is of too much consequence for you to undertake.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: I know what your suit is, Madam, because I was with my Lord when Hammond brought in your message; and I was so sorry for you, I came out on purpose to see you—and, without speaking to my Lord, I could do you a great kindness—if I durst.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: What kindness?

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: But I durst not—No, do not ask me.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I do not. But you have raised my curiosity; and in a mind so distracted as mine, it is cruel to excite one additional pain.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: I am sure I would not add to your grief for the world.—But then, pray do not speak of what I am going to say.—I heard my Lord's lawyer tell him just now, "that as he said he should not know the person again, who committed the offence about which you came, and as the man who informed against him was gone off, there could be no evidence that he did the action, but from a book, a particular pocket-book, of my Lord's, which he forgot to deliver to his servant with the notes and money to return, and which was found upon him at your house: and this, Lord Norland will affirm to be his."—Now, if I did not think I was doing wrong, this is the very book— Takes a pocket-book front his pocket I took it from my Lord's table;— but it would be doing wrong, or I am sure I wish you had it. Looking wishfully at her.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: It will save my life, my husband's and my children's.

sp.speaker: EDWARD,
sp.p: But what is to become of me?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: That Providence, who never punishes the deed, unless the will be an accomplice, shall protect you for saving one, who has only erred in a moment of distraction.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: I never did any thing to offend my Lord in my life;—and I am in such fear of him, I did not think I ever should.—Yet, I cannot refuse you;— take it.— Gives her the book. But pity me, when my Lord shall know of it.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Oh! should he discard you for what you have done, it will embitter every moment of my remaining life.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Do not frighten yourself about that.—I think he loves me too well to discard me quite.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Does he indeed?

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: I think he does;—for often, when we are alone, he presses me to his bosom so fondly, you would not suppose.—And, when my poor nurse died, she called me to her bed-side, and told me (but pray keep it a secret)—she told me I was—his grandchild.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: You are—you are his grand-child—I see,—I feel you are;—for I feel that I am your mother. Embraces him. Oh! take this evidence back returning the book—I cannot receive it from thee, my child;—no, let us all perish, rather than my boy, my only boy, should do an act to stain his conscience, or to lose his grand-father's love.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: The name of the person with whom you lived in your infancy, was Heyland?

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: It was.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p:
I am your mother; Lord Norland's only child, Edward kneels who, for one act of disobedience, have been driven to another part of the globe in
poverty, and forced to leave you, my life, behind. She embraces and raises him. Your father, in his struggles to support us all, has fallen a victim;— but Heaven, which has preserved my child, will save my husband, restore his sense, and once more—

sp.speaker: EDWARD,
sp.p: I hear my Lord's step,—he is coming this way: —Begone, mother, or we are all undone.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: No, let him come —for though his frown should kill me, yet must I thank him for his care of thee.
sp.stage: She advances towards the door to meet him.
sp.p: Falling on her knees. You love me,— 'tis in vain to say you do not: You love my child; and with whatever hardships you have dealt, or still mean to deal by me, I will never cease to think you love me, nor ever cease my gratitude for your goodness.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Where are my servants? Who let this woman in?

div3.stage: She rises, and retreats from him alarmed and confused.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Oh, my Lord, pity her.—Do not let me see her hardly treated—Indeed I cannot bear it.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND,
sp.p: What was your errand here? If to see your child, take him along with you.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I came to see my father;—I have a house too full of such as he already.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: How did she gain admittance?

sp.speaker: HAMMOND.
sp.p: With a petition, which I repeated to your Lordship. Exit Hammond.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Her husband then it was, who— To Lady Eleanor But let him know, for this boy's sake, I will no longer pursue him.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: For that boy's sake you will not pursue his father; but for whose sake are you so tender of that boy? 'Tis for mine, for my sake; and by that I conjure you— Offers to kneel.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Your prayers are vain— To Edward. Go, take leave of your mother for ever, and instantly follow me; or shake hands with me for the last time, and instantly begone with her.

div3.stage: Edward stands between them in doubt for some little time: looks alternately at each with emotions of affection; at last goes to his grandfather, and takes hold of his hand.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Farewell, my Lord, —it almost breaks my heart to part from you;—but, if I have my choice, I must go with my mother.

div3.stage: Lady Eleanor and her Son go off on the opposite side.
Enter Miss WOOBURN and Mrs. PLACID.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Well, my dear, farewell.—I have staid a great while longer than I intended—I certainly forgot to tell Mr. Placid to come back after he had spoken with Lady Eleanor, or he would not have taken the liberty not to have come.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: How often have I lamented the fate of Lord Norland's daughter! But, luckily, I have no personal acquaintance with her, or I should probably feel a great deal more on her account than I do at present.—She had quitted her father's house before I came to it.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: My whole life is passed in endeavouring to make people happy, and yet they won't let me.—I flattered myself, that after I had resigned all pretensions to you, Miss Wooburn, in order to accommodate Sir Robert—that, after I had told both my Lord and him, in what high estimation they stood in each other's opinion, they would of course be friends; or, at least, not have come to any desperate quarrel:—instead of which, what have they done, but, within this hour, had a duel!—and poor Sir Robert—

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake, tell me of Sir Robert—

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p:
You were the only person he mentioned after
he received his wound; and such encomiums as he uttered—

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Good Heaven! If he is in danger, it will be vain to endeavour to conceal what I shall suffer.

div3.stage: Retires a few paces to conceal her emotions.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Was my husband there?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: He was one of the seconds.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Then he shall not stir out of his house this month, for it.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: He is not likely; for he is hurt too.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: A great deal hurt?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Don't alarm yourself.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: I don't.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Nay, if you had heard what he said!

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: What did he say?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: How tenderly he spoke of you to all his friends—

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: But what did he say?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: He said you had imperfections.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Then he told a falsehood.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: But he acknowledged they were such as only evinced a superior understanding to the rest of your sex;—and that your heart—

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID,
sp.p: I am sure I am very sorry that any misfortune has happened to him, poor, silly man! But I do not suppose drying up her tears at once he will die.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: If you will behave kind to him, I should suppose not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Mr. Harmony, if Mr. Placid is either dying or dead, I shall behave with very great tenderness; but if I find him alive and likely to live, I will lead him such a life as he has not led a long time.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Then you mean to be kind? But, my dear Miss Wooburn, going to her why this seeming grief? Sir Robert is still living; and should he die of his wounds, you may at least console yourself, that it was not your cruelty which killed him.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Rather than have such a weight on my conscience, I would comply with the most extravagant of his desires, and suffer his cruelty to be the death of me.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: If those are your sentiments, it is my advice that you pay him a visit in his affliction.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Oh no, Mr. Harmony, I would not for the universe. Mrs. Placid, do you think it would be proper?

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: No, I think it would not—Consider, my dear, you are no longer a wife, but a single Lady, and would you run into the clutches of a man?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: He has no clutches, Madam; he is ill in bed, and totally helpless.—But, upon recollection, it would, perhaps, be needless to go; for he may be too ill to admit you.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: If that is the case, all respect to my situation, my character, sinks before the strong desire of seeing him once more. Oh! were I even married to another, I feel, that in spite of all my private declarations, or public vows, I should fly from him, to pay my duty where it was first plighted.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: My coach is at the door; shall I take you to his house? Come, Mrs. Placid, wave all ceremonious motives on the present melancholy occasion, and go along with Miss Wooburn and me.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: But, Mrs. Placid, perhaps poor Mr. Placid is in want of your attendance at home.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: No, they were both carried in the same carriage to Sir Robert's.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN,
sp.stage: As Harmony leads her to the door.
sp.p: Oh! how I long to see my dear husband, that I may console him!

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Oh! how I long to see my dear husband, that I may quarrel with him!Exeunt.

head.stage: The Hall at Sir ROBERT RAMBLE's.

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: Porter, porter, how can you sleep at this time of the day?—It is only eight o'clock.

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: What did you want, Mr. William?

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: To tell you my master must not be disturbed, and so you must not let in a single creature.

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: Mr. William, this is no less than the third time I have received those orders within this half hour: —First, from the butler, then from the valet, and now from the footman.—Do you all suppose I am stupid?

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: I was bid to tell you. I have only done what I was desired; and mind you do the same. Exit.

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: I'll do my duty, I warrant you. I'll do my duty. A loud rapping at the door And there's a rap to put my duty to the trial. Opens the door.

div3.stage: Enter HARMONY, Miss WOOBURN, and Mrs. PLACID.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p:
These ladies come on a visit to Sir Robert.
Desire one of the servants to conduct them to him instantly.

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, that is impossible—My master is not —

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: We know he is at home, and therefore we can take no denial.

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: I own he is at home, Sir; but indeed he is not in a situation—

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: We know his situation.

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: Then, Madam, you must suppose he is not to be disturbed. I have strict orders not to let in a single soul.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: This Lady, you must be certain, is an exception.

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: No Lady can be an exception in my master's present state; for I believe, Sir, but perhaps I should not speak of it, I believe my master is nearly gone.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Oh! support me, Heaven!

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: But has he his senses?

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: Not very clearly, I believe.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Harmony, let me see him before they are quite lost.

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: It is as much as my place is worth, to let a creature farther than this hall; for my master is but in the next room.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: That is a dining-room. Is not he in bed?

sp.speaker: HARMONY,
sp.p: In cases of wounds, the patient is oftentimes propped up in his chair.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Does he talk at all?

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I heard him just now very loud.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN,
sp.p: I think I hear him rave.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: No, that murmuring is the voice of other persons.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: The Doctors in consultation, I apprehend.—Has he taken any thing?

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: A great deal, I believe, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: No amputation, I hope?

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: What, Madam?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: He does not understand you. To Miss Wooburn. —Come, will you go back?

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: Do, my Lady, and call in the morning.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p:
By that time he may be totally insensible, and
die without knowing how much I am attached to him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: And my husband may die without knowing how much I am enraged with him!—Mr. Harmony, never mind this foolish man, but force your way into the next room.

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, you must not. Pray, Mr. Harmony, pray, Ladies, go away.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Yes, I must go from my husband's house for ever; never to see that, or him again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: She is fainting—open the windows—give her air.

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: Pray go away:—There is plenty of air in the streets, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Scoundrel! Your impertinence is insupportable. Open these doors; I insist on their being opened.

div3.stage: He thrusts at a door in the centre of the stage; it opens, and discovers Sir Robert and Mr. Placid at a table surrounded by a company of Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p:
A song—a song—another song— Miss Wooburn, all astonishment, is supported by Mr. Harmony and Mrs. Placid—the Porter runs off. Oh! what do I see!—Women! Ladies! Celestial beings we were talking of.—Can this be real? Sir Robert and Mr. Placid come forward—Sir Robert perceiving it is Miss Wooburn, turns himself to the company Gentlemen, Gentlemen, married
men and single men, hear me thus publicly renounce every woman on earth but this; and swear henceforward to be devoted to none but my own wife. Goes to her in raptures.

sp.speaker: PLACID,
sp.stage: Looking at Mrs. Placid, then turning to the Company.
sp.p: Gentlemen, Gentlemen, married men and single men, hear me thus publicly declare, I will henceforth be master;—and from this time forward, will be obeyed by my wife. Sir Robert waves his hand, and the door is closed on the company of Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Mr. Placid—Mr. Placid, are not you afraid?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: No, Madam;—I have consulted my friends, I have drank two bottles of wine, and I never intend to be afraid again.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN,
sp.p: Can it be, that I see you without a wound?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: No, my life, that you do not; for I have a wound through my heart, which none but you can cure. But in despair of your aid, I have flown to wine, to give me a temporary relief by the loss of reflection.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Mr. Placid, you will be sober in the morning.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Yes, my dear; and I will take care that you shall be dutiful in the morning.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p:
For shame! How can you treat Mrs. Placid thus? You would not, if you knew what kind things she has been saying of you; and how anxious
she was when I told her you were wounded in a duel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Was not I, Mr. Harmony?Bursting into tears.

sp.speaker: PLACID,
sp.stage: Aside to Harmony and Sir Robert.
sp.p: I did not know she could cry;—I never saw it before, and it has made me sober in an instant.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Mr. Placid, I rely on you to conduct me immediately from this house.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: That I protest against; and will use even violent measures to prevent it.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Lord Norland.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: He will protect me.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Who shall protect you in my house but I? My Lord, she is under my protection; and if you offer to take her from me, I'll exert the authority of a husband, and lock her up.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND,
sp.p: Have you been deluded hither, and wish to leave the place with me? Tell me instantly, that I may know how to act.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: My Lord, I am ready to go with you, but—

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p:
—But you find she is inclined to stay; and do have
some compassion upon two people that are so fond of you.

div3.stage: Enter Mr. SOLUS, drest in a suit of white clothes.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I am married!—I am married! —Wish me joy! I am married!

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I cannot give you joy, for envy.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Nay, I do not know whether you will envy me much when you see my spouse—I cannot say she was exactly my choice. However, she is my wife now; and that is a name so endearing, I think I love her better since the ceremony has been performed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: And pray, when did it take place?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: This moment. We are now returning from a friend's house, where we have been joined; and I felt myself so happy, I could not pass Sir Robert's door, without calling to tell him of my good fortune.—And, as I see your Lady here, Sir Robert, I guess you are just married too; and so I'll hand my wife out of the carriage, and introduce the two Brides to each other. Exit Solus.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: You see, my Lord, what construction Mr. Solus has put on this Lady's visit to me. And by Heaven, if you take her away, it will be said, that she came and offered herself, and that I reject her!

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: Such a report would kill me.

div3.stage: Enter SOLUS, leading on Miss SPINSTER.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Mistress Solus. Introducing her.

sp.speaker: HARMONY,
sp.p: My Relation! Dear Madam, by what strange turn of fortune do I see you become a wife?

sp.speaker: Mrs. SOLUS.
sp.p: Mr. Harmony, it is a weakness I acknowledge; but you can never want an excuse for me, when you call to mind "the scarcity of provisions."

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Mr. Harmony, I have loved her ever since you told me she spoke so well of me behind my back.

div3.stage: And whispers Mr. HARMONY, who follows him off.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I agree with you, Mr. Solus, that this is a most excellent proof of a person's disposition; and in consideration, Sir Robert, that, throughout all our many disagreements, you have still preserved a respect for my character in my absence, I do at last say to that Lady, she has my consent to trust you again.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And she will trust me; I see it in her smiles. Oh! unexpected ecstasy!

sp.speaker: HARMONY,
sp.stage: Holding a letter in his hand.
sp.p:
Amidst those bright prospects of joy which this company are contemplating, I come to announce an event that ought to cloud the splendour of the horizon.—A worthy, but an ill-fated man, whom
ye were all acquainted with, has just breathed his last.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Do you mean the husband of my daughter?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Do you mean my nephew?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Is it my friend?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And my old acquaintance?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Did Mr. Irwin possess all those titles you have given him, Gentlemen? Was he your son? To Lord Norland Your nephew? To Solus Your friend? To Mr. Placid And your old acquaintance? To Sir Robert—How strange he did not know it!

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: He did know it.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Still more strange that he should die for want, and not apply to any of you!

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: What! Die for want in London! Starve in the midst of plenty!

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: No; but he seized that plenty, where law, where honour, where every social and religious tie forbad the trespass; and in punishment of the guilt, has become his own executioner.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Then my daughter is wretched, and her boy involved in his father's infamy.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: The fear of his ghost haunting me, will disturb the joys of my married life.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Mrs. Placid, Mrs. Placid, my complying with your injunctions in respect of Mr. Irwin, will make me miserable for ever.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN.
sp.p: I wish he had applied to me.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And as I refused him his request. I would give half my estate he had not applied to me.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: And a man who always spoke so well of you all behind your backs!—I dare say, that, in his dying moments, there was not one of you whom he did not praise for some virtue.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: No, no—when he was dying he would be more careful of what he said.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Sir Robert, good-day. Settle your marriage as you and your Lady shall approve; you have my good wishes. But my spirits have received too great a shock to be capable of any other impression at present.

sp.speaker: Miss WOOBURN,
sp.p: Nay, stay, my Lord.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p:
And, Mrs. Solus, let me hand you into your carriage to your company; but excuse my going home with you. My spirits have received too
great a shock, for me to be capable of any other impression at present.

sp.speaker: HARMONY,
sp.p: Now, so loth am I to see any of you, only for a moment, in grief, while I have the power to relieve you, that I cannot help—Yes, my philanthropy will get the better of my justice.

div3.stage: Goes to the door, and leads on Lady Eleanor, Irwin, and Edward.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND
sp.stage: Runs to Irwin, and embraces him.
sp.p: My son! Irwin falls on his knees I take a share in all your offences—The worst of accomplices, while I impelled you to them.

sp.speaker: IRWIN,
sp.p: I come to offer my returning reason; to offer my vows, that, while that reason continue, so long will I be penitent for the phrensy which put your life in danger.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR,
sp.stage: Moving timidly to her Father, leading Edward by the hand.
sp.p: I come to offer you this child, this affectionate child; who, in the midst of our caresses, droops his head and pines for your forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Ah! there is a corner of my heart left to receive him. Embraces him.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Then, pray, my Lord, suffer the corner to be large enough to hold my mother.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: My heart is softened, and receives you all. Embraces Lady Eleanor, who falls on her knees; he then turns to Harmony—Mr. Harmony, I thank you, I most sincerely thank you for this, the joyfullest moment of my life. I not only experience release from misery, but return to happiness.

sp.speaker: HARMONY
sp.stage: Goes hastily to Solus, and leads him to Irwin; then turns to Mr. and Mrs. Placid.
sp.p: And now, that I see you all reconciled, I can say, there are not two enemies in the whole circle of my acquaintance, that I have not within these three days made friends.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Very true, Harmony; for we should never have known half how well we all love one another, if you had not told us.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: And yet, my good friends, notwithstanding the merit you may attribute to me, I have one most tremendous fault; and it weighs so heavy on my conscience, I would confess what it is, but that you might hereafter call my veracity in question.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: My dear Harmony, without a fault, you would not be a proper companion for any of us.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: And while a man like you, may have (among so many virtues) some faults; let us hope there may be found in each of us, (among all our faults) some virtues.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord,—and notwithstanding all our faults, it is my sincere wish, that the world may speak well of us—behind our backs.

lg.l: "EACH has his fault," we readily allow,
To this Decree, our dearest friends must bow;
One is too careless, one is too correct,
All, save our own sweet self, has some defect:
And characters to ev'ry virtue dear,
Sink from a hint, or suffer by a sneer.
"Sir Harry Blink! Oh, he's a worthy man,
"Still anxious to do all the good he can;
"To aid distress, wou'd share his last poor guinea,
"Delights in kindness—but then, what a ninny!"
Lady Doll Primrose says to Lady Sly,
"You know Miss Tidlikins? Yes—looks awry—
"She's going to be married,—that won't mend it;—
"They say she'll have a fortune,—and she'll spend it.
"I hope your La'aship visits Lady Hearty,
"We meet to-night—a most delightful party.
"I don't like Dowagers, who would be young,
"And 'twixt ourselves they say—She has a tongue."
If such the general blame that all await,
Say, can our Author 'scape the general fate?
Some will dislike the saucy truths she teaches,
Fond bachelors, and wives who wear the breeches.
"Let me be wedded to a handsome youth,"
Cries old Miss Mumblelove, without a tooth.
"These worn-out Beaux, because they've heavy purses,
"Expect us, spinsters, to become their nurses.
"To love, and be beloved 's the happy wife,
"A mutual passion is the charm of life."
"Marriage is Heaven's best gift, we must believe it,
"Yet some with weak ideas can't conceive it.—
"Poor Lady Sobwell's grief the town wou'd stun;
"Oh, Tiffany! Your mistress is undone.
"Dear Ma'am—I hope my Lord is well—don't cry—
"Hav'n't I cause?—The monster will not die—
"The reason why I married him, is clear,
"I fondly thought he cou'd not live a year:
"But now his dropsy's better, and his cough—
"Not the least chance for that to take him off.
"I, that cou'd have young husbands now in plenty,
"Sha'n't be a widow till I'm one-and-twenty—
"No lovely weeds—No sweet dishevell'd hair—
"Oh! I cou'd cry my eyes out in despair."
Sir Tristram Testy, worn with age and gout;
Within, all spleen, and flannel all without;
Roars from his elbow-chair, "Reach me my crutches,
"Oh! if Death had my wife within his clutches,
"With what delight her funeral meats I'd gobble,
"And tho', not dance upon her grave, I'd hobble;
"No longer then, my peace she could unhinge,
"I shou'd cut capers soon, tries to jump, and stumbles
Zounds! What a twinge!"—
These playful pictures of discordant life,
We bring to combat discontent and strife,
And, by the force of contrast, sweetly prove
The charm that waits on fond and faithful love:
When suited years, and pliant tempers join,
And the heart glows with energy divine,
As the lov'd offspring of the happy pair
Oft climb the knee, the envied kiss to share.
Such joys this happy country long has known,
Rear'd in the Cot, reflected from the Throne;
Oh! may the glorious zeal, the loyal stand
Which nobly animate this envied land,
Secure to every breast, with glad increase,
The heartfelt blessings of domestic peace!
